questions.text: In lichen planus, nails deformities include all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beau's lines Among the given options, Beau’s line is not a feature of Lichen Planus Nail Changes in Lichen Planus Dorsal Nail Pterygium ( Most specific) Irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges with thinning of the nail plate (Most common ) Pup-tent sign Subungual hyperkeratosis Permanent destruction of nails Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Highyeild:

Beau’s line These are indentations that run across the nails ( transverse depression) Cause: The indentations can appear when growth in the area under the cuticle is interrupted by injury or severe illness Usually, multiple nails are affected at a time. The timing of the insult can be estimated by measuring the distance from the proximal nail fold to Beau’s line, as fingernails grow approximately 0.1mm per day.

questions.text: A patient has thinned nails, onycholysis, tent sign and nail dystrophy. What else is expected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Longitudinal ridging of nails Lichen planus is autoimmune disease which involves the nails. Patients often have nail changes in the form of thinned nails, onycholysis, tent sign and nail dystrophy. Longitudinal ridging of nails is also seen.

Highyeild:

Features of Nail LP Pterygium (dorsal pterygium)-Most classical feature. The proximal nail-fold fuses with the proximal portion of the nail-bed Thinning of nail plate Longitudinal ridging Subungual hyperkeratosis Tenting or pup-tent sign is a result of nail bed involvement that elevates the nail plate in a tent shape Twenty nail dystrophy (Trachyonychia)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Anemia is not a sign of lichen planus Option C- Non scarring alopecia would have been correct if the question would point to a diagnosis of alopecia areata. Option D- oil drop sign is seen in psoriasis and not in lichen planus.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female accountant by occupation comes to the hospital with the complaint of a nail deformity. She gave a history of enteric fever 3 months ago following which these changes on the nail started. On examination of her nails there is a transverse groove on all her fingers and toenails. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beau’s lines The given clinical scenario of a history of enteric fever (systemic disease) with the transverse longitudinal groove on all her fingernails and toenails is suggestive of Beau’s lines.

Highyeild:

Beau’s line These are indentations that run across the nails ( transverse depression) Cause: The indentations can appear when growth in the area under the cuticle is interrupted by injury or severe illness Usually, multiple nails are affected at a time. The timing of the insult can be estimated by measuring the distance from the proximal nail fold to Beau’s line, as fingernails grow approximately 0.1mm per day.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Koilonychia: They are soft nails that look scooped out. The depression usually is large enough to hold a drop of liquid. Often, spoon nails are a sign of iron deficiency anemia or a liver condition known as hemochromatosis. Option B. Mees lines: aka Aldrich or Reynolds' lines which are transverse white bands on the nail plate laid down during periods of stress. Common associations are poisoning (arsenic, thallium, fluorosis), severe infection, renal disease, cardiac failure, and malignant disease. Option D. Trachyonychia: It is a disorder of the nail unit that most commonly presents with rough, longitudinally ridged nails (opaque trachyonychia) or less frequently, uniform, opalescent nails with pits (shiny trachyonychia).

questions.text: Match the following nail signs with the corresponding diseases: Nail signs Diseases. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a To match the nail signs with the corresponding diseases, the correct answer is: Flag sign: Leprosy Round finger pad sign: Scleroderma Pup tent sign: Nail bed lichen planus Vieira sign: Endemic pemphigus foliaceus Therefore, the correct code for matching the nail signs with the diseases is: 1 - b, 2 - c, 3 - d, 4 - a (Option B)

Highyeild:

Nail psoriasis features 10–80% of psoriatic patients. Patients with nail involvement have an increased incidence of psoriatic arthritis Oil drop or Salmon patch · A translucent, yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil beneath the nail plate. Pathognomonic of nail psoriasis Subungual hyperkeratosis · Excessive deposits of keratin on the nail bed. Nail plate pitting • Most common feature • Pattern is random, deep and irregular • Also called “thimble pits” • Pit is due to involvement of the proximal nail matrix Onycholysis • Separation of the nail plate from its underlying attachment to the nail bed (secondary to subungual hyperkeratosis) Leuconychia (white streaks on nail) Splinter hemorrhages

Extraedge:

Mnemonic to remember nail psoriasis features Nail- POLISH P = P itting O = O il drop, O nycholysis L = L euconychia I = I rregular (pits) S = S plinter hemorrhage H = H yperkeratosis (subungual)

questions.text: A 14-year-old male chronic smoker presented to dermatology OPD with a 7-month history of nail changes. His general physical examination was normal. On local examination, all 20 nails were abnormal with onycholysis, subungual hyperkeratosis, and blackish discoloration. Which of the following conditions is not known to be associated with this disorder?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Darier’s disease The given clinical scenario is suggestive of 20-nail dystrophy aka trachyonychia. Darier’s disease does not present with 20 nail dystrophy. Alopecia areata, LP, and amyloidosis present with 20-nail dystrophy. Nail change is Darier’s disease: White and red longitudinal bands (longitudinal erythronychia), Onychorrhexis, Onycholysis, Brittle nails, Splinter hemorrhages, Longitudinal ridges of nails, Wedge-shaped subungual hyperkeratosis and V-shaped nicking/notching at the distal end of the nail plate

Highyeild:

Twenty-nail dystrophy aka trachyonychia Most commonly occurs in childhood or young males 10-20 years old Cause: Lichen planus Eczema Psoriasis Alopecia areata Features: Nails become grubby, rough, and brittle Some nails may become distorted Nail examination shows longitudinal ridging, pitting, roughening, and splitting Nails lose their lustre and may change to a muddy, greyish-white color ( sand-blasted appearance ) Treatment: Griseofulvin and other antifungals. Systemic, topical, and intrapersonal corticosteroids Topical PUVA

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Alopecia areata: Pitting, trachyonychia, red-spotted lunulae, longitudinal ridging, punctate leukonychia, and pigmented longitudinal bands. Option B . Lichen planus: Nail plate ridging and fissuring, onycholysis, nail bed, dorsal pterygium, anonychia, and nail bed atrophy Option C . Amyloidosis: Brittleness, increased fragility, trachyonychia, longitudinal ridging, and subungual splinter hemorrhages.

questions.text: A 24-year-female presents with patchy hair loss in the right temporal and occipital region. Examination reveals non-scarring alopecia. Her nail changes are likely to be
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pitting Patchy hair loss with non scarring alopecia is suggestive of alopecia areata. Nail changes are likely to be in the form of geometric pitting (transverse and longitudinal)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- salmon patch would be the answer give the question was pointing to psoriasis. psoriasis does not cause hair loss. Option C- Tent sign would be seen in lichen planus which would have scarring alopecia Option D- Yellow discoloration would be seen in tinea. The MCQ is not of tinea capitis as there is no easy pluckability mentioned. Also, the age is not appropriate for tinea capitis (more seen in children)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Nail-Patella Syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nail has dorsal pterygium Nail changes in Nail-Patella Syndrome characterised by absent or underdeveloped nails and discoloured , characteristic triangular lunula is seen. Dorsal nail pterygium is a characteristic finding of Lichen Planus.

Highyeild:

Nail Patella Syndrome Rare genetic syndrome, Autosomal dominant, mutation is LMX1B gene aka Hereditary Onycho-osteodysplasia or Fong disease Features : Apparent at birth or early childhood Decreased muscle mass in upper arms and legs Problem gaining weight Nail: Absence or underdeveloped fingernails and toenails Patella: Often asymmetrical involvement Malformed, underdeveloped, or absent Iliac horns Bow leg deformity Lester sign: Dark pigmentation around the iris resembling cloverleaf Open-angle glaucoma Hematuria and Proteinuria Diagnosis: Clinical and genetic testing Treatment: Symptomatic management

questions.text: Blue lunula is seen in which of the following entity?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wilson’s disease Azure or blue lunula is a feature of Wilson’s

Highyeild:

Wilson disease It is an autosomal recessive disorder Caused by ATP7B mutations. Pathogenesis: deficiency of a copper transporting ATPase Failure of biliary copper excretion causes its accumulation in the body. Failure to synthesise ceruloplasmin. Copper causes tissue toxicity and end-organ damage. Features: Liver involvement:- Hepatosplenomegaly, Acute Hepatitis. Brain involvement:- Neuropsychiatric manifestations Eye involvement:- Kayser-Fleischer ring, sunflower cataracts Renal tubular damage Arthropathy:-Osteoporosis Cardiomyopathy Dermatological findings: Blue lunulae of nails (Most specific), Xeroderma, grey-brown hyperpigmentation over extensor aspects of legs, and cheilitis Management: Penicillamine, Zinc acetate, Liver transplant

questions.text: A 50 year old patient on novilumab has pruritic and urticarial lesions. Histopathology shows subepidermal blister and IgG and C3 deposition along the dermoepidermal junction. Which of the following matches with given history and immunofluorescence ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bullous pemphigoid The diagnosis is bullous pemphigoid due to a history of itchy, urticarial lesions along with the sub epidermal blister and IgG and C3 deposits on DIF. The image shown in the picture is a linear deposit of antibodies and complement along the dermo epidermal junction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- It is not pemphigus vulgaris as it has an epidermal blister not a sub epidermal blister and would not have a linear deposit . Instead it would have a fishnet appearance in epidermis Option B- it is not pemphigus foliaceus as like vulgaris it would have a fishnet appearance in the epidermis. Option D- in dermatitis herpetiformis, the lesions are pruritic as in the question. Also, there will be a sub epidermal blister. But it would not have a linear deposit of IgG. Instead there will be IgA in a granular pattern at the tip of dermal papillae.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent itchy, erythematous plaques over scalp and sacral area. There is history of joint pains. Nail findings are as shown. The likely diagnosis is :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Psoriasis Lesions which are itchy, erythematous on the scalp and sacral areas along with nail pitting and salmon patch as shown in the picture points to a diagnosis of psoriasis. Joint pains points to psoriatic arthritis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Lichen planus will not have red itchy lesions. Purple lesions are seen instead. Also, there will be no joint involvement. Pitting would also not be seen. Option C- there is no alopecia mentioned in the question. Option D- Tinea would have yellow discoloration on nail without pitting. The history if the MCQ is also not s/o tinea

questions.text: Nail finding of tinea are all except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pitting Features of tinea unguium/ Onychomycosis Yellow discoloration of nail Thickened nail plate Subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis Tunnelling under the nail plate (tunnels in the subungual hyperkeratotic tissue)
